entry.value: This page features some of the different types of data copy available in Rapid.

For this page we will be using a grid control that has some pre-defined data already inside of it, ready to be manipulated. The repopulate button can be used to reset this grid back to it's original data. To save space on this page we will only be covering a few of the data copies, namely replace, append and row merge.
To begin, let's enter some details about a person to add to our grid. Fill in the information below and click on the populate button. For this type of data copy we will be using replace.
alert("Please fill out the missing details");

If you have access to Rapid Design you may notice that the data copy is actually nested within a logic statement. This checks the above controls to see if they are empty, and will not copy into the grid if they are. Going into this logic statement will reveal a lot of data copies, with some listing as 'row merge'. The final result is our replace.

The replace option for data copying is worth a quick explanation, and it will make sense as to why all of our previous grid data gets replaced. The replace data copy type is very greedy and will replace everything in the specified location, even if identifying fields are used. With the replace data copy type explained and tested we are ready to move on to the next type, append!
Appending data will add in a new row of data into our grid, positioned at the bottom. This type of data copy is a lot friendlier to use as it is not harsh on data deletion.
alert("Please fill out the missing details");

The next type of data copy is row merge. If you have access to Rapid Design you may have noticed that we have already been using row merges for the past two data copies! The way in which we have used row merging so far is to copy all of the data you have entered into our input boxes inside of a datastore! The datastore then uses the data copy types we have mentioned, replace and append, to copy into our grid to generate a new set of results.
alert("Please fill out the missing details");

As you can see by testing, row merging will replace one row with the data filled out above. By default the top row will be replaced. Whilst not immediately useful in this sense as it is right now, in the right combinations it can be incredibly valuable. A good example is included in the hint to the right.
That's all for this page! The rest of the data copy types can be found by following this link:

[{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P6_C35_","text":"Replacing data is a good way of updating outdated information with newer, more accurate information about a specific subject, providing that you are aware of what occurs when using the replace action. Our 'Populate grid' button has 4 separate data copy actions, used to showcase replacing, but it goes through a datastore to make things easier. It is also possible, and more ideal, to use a bulk data copy to do the same.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P6_C113_","text":"Appending data is likely going to be the main type of data copy that will be used in your Rapid applications. As it adds to your data sets it is a lot more reusable. Currently, for this example, we are not worried about duplicate data, however it is very easy to code in a check for duplicate data.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P6_C148_","text":"An example of a good way to use row merging is what we currently use to populate the grid control when the 'Populate grid' button is pressed. We start by replacing data in the datastore and then row merging the rest of the data. Whilst the populate button currently removes all other data, if we change the results to our page load event, copy into our datastore we can then set one replace and the rest as row merging to populate our grid from our datastore. For a visual example of this click on this hint to go to our tutorial on how to make a desktop app.","type":"hover"}]

{"controlHints":[{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P6_C35_","text":"Replacing data is a good way of updating outdated information with newer, more accurate information about a specific subject, providing that you are aware of what occurs when using the replace action. Our 'Populate grid' button has 4 separate data copy actions, used to showcase replacing, but it goes through a datastore to make things easier. It is also possible, and more ideal, to use a bulk data copy to do the same.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P6_C113_","text":"Appending data is likely going to be the main type of data copy that will be used in your Rapid applications. As it adds to your data sets it is a lot more reusable. Currently, for this example, we are not worried about duplicate data, however it is very easy to code in a check for duplicate data.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P6_C148_","text":"An example of a good way to use row merging is what we currently use to populate the grid control when the 'Populate grid' button is pressed. We start by replacing data in the datastore and then row merging the rest of the data. Whilst the populate button currently removes all other data, if we change the results to our page load event, copy into our datastore we can then set one replace and the rest as row merging to populate our grid from our datastore. For a visual example of this click on this hint to go to our tutorial on how to make a desktop app.","type":"hover"}]}

query.SQL: select forename, surname, birthday, gender from people where id > 3 and id < 15 or id > 99 and id < 111 order by RANDOM()

page.htmlBody:
This page features some of the different types of data copy available in Rapid.

For this page we will be using a grid control that has some pre-defined data already inside of it, ready to be manipulated. The repopulate button can be used to reset this grid back to it's original data. To save space on this page we will only be covering a few of the data copies, namely replace, append and row merge.To begin, let's enter some details about a person to add to our grid. Fill in the information below and click on the populate button. For this type of data copy we will be using replace.
First name
Last name
Birthday
Gender
If you have access to Rapid Design you may notice that the data copy is actually nested within a logic statement. This checks the above controls to see if they are empty, and will not copy into the grid if they are. Going into this logic statement will reveal a lot of data copies, with some listing as 'row merge'. The final result is our replace.The replace option for data copying is worth a quick explanation, and it will make sense as to why all of our previous grid data gets replaced. The replace data copy type is very greedy and will replace everything in the specified location, even if identifying fields are used. With the replace data copy type explained and tested we are ready to move on to the next type, append!Appending data will add in a new row of data into our grid, positioned at the bottom. This type of data copy is a lot friendlier to use as it is not harsh on data deletion.
First name
Last name
Birthday
Gender
The next type of data copy is row merge. If you have access to Rapid Design you may have noticed that we have already been using row merges for the past two data copies! The way in which we have used row merging so far is to copy all of the data you have entered into our input boxes inside of a datastore! The datastore then uses the data copy types we have mentioned, replace and append, to copy into our grid to generate a new set of results.
First name
Last name
Birthday
Gender
As you can see by testing, row merging will replace one row with the data filled out above. By default the top row will be replaced. Whilst not immediately useful in this sense as it is right now, in the right combinations it can be incredibly valuable. A good example is included in the hint to the right.That's all for this page! The rest of the data copy types can be found by following this link: Secondary data copy page
ForenameSurnameDate of birthGender
page.name: 04_dataCopyTypes1

rolesHtml.html:
This page features some of the different types of data copy available in Rapid.

For this page we will be using a grid control that has some pre-defined data already inside of it, ready to be manipulated. The repopulate button can be used to reset this grid back to it's original data. To save space on this page we will only be covering a few of the data copies, namely replace, append and row merge.To begin, let's enter some details about a person to add to our grid. Fill in the information below and click on the populate button. For this type of data copy we will be using replace.
First name
Last name
Birthday
Gender
If you have access to Rapid Design you may notice that the data copy is actually nested within a logic statement. This checks the above controls to see if they are empty, and will not copy into the grid if they are. Going into this logic statement will reveal a lot of data copies, with some listing as 'row merge'. The final result is our replace.The replace option for data copying is worth a quick explanation, and it will make sense as to why all of our previous grid data gets replaced. The replace data copy type is very greedy and will replace everything in the specified location, even if identifying fields are used. With the replace data copy type explained and tested we are ready to move on to the next type, append!Appending data will add in a new row of data into our grid, positioned at the bottom. This type of data copy is a lot friendlier to use as it is not harsh on data deletion.
First name
Last name
Birthday
Gender
The next type of data copy is row merge. If you have access to Rapid Design you may have noticed that we have already been using row merges for the past two data copies! The way in which we have used row merging so far is to copy all of the data you have entered into our input boxes inside of a datastore! The datastore then uses the data copy types we have mentioned, replace and append, to copy into our grid to generate a new set of results.
First name
Last name
Birthday
Gender
As you can see by testing, row merging will replace one row with the data filled out above. By default the top row will be replaced. Whilst not immediately useful in this sense as it is right now, in the right combinations it can be incredibly valuable. A good example is included in the hint to the right.That's all for this page! The rest of the data copy types can be found by following this link: Secondary data copy page

page.title: Data copy types
